title: renewable energy: Turning waste into wealth: NexGen Energia's innovative CBG plant promotes eco-friendly sustainable energy - The Economic Times
text: NexGen Energia, a leading renewable energy company, is all set to mark a significant milestone in India. In a groundbreaking move, the company will unveil one of India’s first compressed biogas (CBG) plants, leveraging the potential of Napier grass, in the town of Padruana, Kushinagar, Uttar Pradesh. The inauguration is scheduled for March.NexGen Energia’s pioneering venture aims to address the challenges of waste management and provide a renewable energy solution that promotes environmental well-being.Model For Future ProjectsThe CBG plant is expected to contribute significantly to the reduction of the nation’s carbon footprint, catering to the increasing energy demand while ensuring a minimal impact on the environment.The plant, equipped with state-of-the-art technology and modern infrastructure, has undergone rigorous testing and quality checks, ensuring the production of clean and sustainable energy.Speaking about the upcoming launch, Dr Piyush Dwivedi, chairman, NexGen Energia, said, “We are extremely proud and thrilled to introduce India’s first compressed biogas plant using Napier grass. This endeavour aligns perfectly with our commitment to combat the climate crisis and work towards a cleaner and greener India. We believe this breakthrough will pave the way for a brighter future, both environmentally director, and economically.”A Game-ChangerThe CBG plant is expected to create numerous employment opportunities in the region, stimulating local economic growth. Additionally, the project will contribute to the government’s vision of reducing reliance on fossil fuels and promoting sustainable alternatives.The company is leading the charge in harnessing the potential of Napier grass as a major feedstock for power generation. With 38 projects lined up, NexGen Energia is poised to revolutionise India’s energy landscape.Nishant Tiwari, director, NexGen Energia, said, “This is a game-changer for clean energy. The establishment of these 38 compressed biogas plants will not only reduce our reliance on fossil fuels but also contribute to waste management solutions. This project presents a tremendous opportunity for the biogas industry. The expansion of CBG plants will boost job creation, stimulate the rural economy and contribute to achieving our net-zero emission targets.”.
